html.p: The following is a summary of the reading from the textbook to give you an idea of what is expected to know before coming to class. It does not replace reading the textbook.
A scalar field is a function that gives us a single value of some variable for every point in space.

For example, temperature is a scalar field (see other examples in Section 1.2 of the texbook). There are three commonly used representations for a two-dimensional scalar field: Contour Maps, Color-Coding and Relief Maps (see Section 1.2.1). A vector is a quantity that has both a magnitude and a direction in space. Vectors are used to describe physical quantities such as velocity, momentum, acceleration and force, associated with an object. However, when we try to describe a system that consists of a large number of objects (e.g., moving water, snow, rain, ...) we need to assign a vector to each individual point in space. Fluid flow is probably the most intuitive example of a vector field (see examples in Section 1.4 of the texbook)

The gravitational field of the Earth is another example of a vector field that can be used to describe the interaction between an object with mass and the Earth. The Electric Field is very analogous to the Gravitational Field.

The force between electrically charged objects at rest is called the electrostatic force. However, unlike mass in gravitational force, there are two types of electric charge: positive and negative. The electrostatic force between charged objects falls off as the inverse square of their distance of separation, and can be either attractive or repulsive. html.p: There are two types of observed electric charge, which we designate as positive and negative. The convention was derived from Benjamin Franklin’s experiments. He rubbed a glass rod with silk and called the charges on the glass rod positive. He rubbed sealing wax with fur and called the charge on the sealing wax negative. Like charges repel and opposite charges attract each other. The unit of charge is called the Coulomb (C).

An electron carries one unit of negative charge,[mathjaxinline]-e[/mathjaxinline] , while a proton carries one unit of positive charge, [mathjaxinline]+e[/mathjaxinline] . In a closed system, the total amount of charge is conserved since charge can neither be created nor destroyed. A charge can, however, be transferred from one body to another.
